Help us to give a warm welcome to Mrs. Amiee Erfourth. Amiee will begin leading us on Tuesday, September 8, 2020 as the next Superintendent of Benzie County Central Schools.

Amiee has served Benzie County Central Schools for the last 20 years. She began her career as a first grade teacher at Betsie Valley Elementary and worked in that position for 14 years. The last 6 years have been spent as the principal of Betsie Valley Elementary.

Amiee received her Bachelor’s of Science degree in elementary education from Central Michigan University and completed her Master’s of Arts degree in Administration from Central Michigan as well.

Amiee and her husband, Dan, have 3 children. Their oldest son, Evan, just started his first year at Michigan Technological University. Their son, Aidan, is in middle school at Benzie Central, and their daughter, Ava, is a 4th grader at Betsie Valley Elementary.
Welcome, Superintendent Erfourth!

#benziecentraldistrictfacebookpage✅
THE MARIGOLD EFFECT
“Many experienced gardeners follow a concept called companion planting: placing certain vegetables and plants near each other to improve growth for one or both plants. For example, rose growers plant garlic near their roses because it repels bugs and prevents fungal diseases. Among companion plants, the marigold is one of the best: It protects a wide variety of plants from pests and harmful weeds. If you plant a marigold beside most any garden vegetable, that vegetable will grow big and strong and healthy, protected and encouraged by its marigold.

Marigolds exist in our schools as well – encouraging, supporting and nurturing growing teachers on their way to maturity. If you can find at least one marigold in your school and stay close to them, you will grow. Find more than one and you will positively thrive.”

Together,
Mrs. Crossman 🐾

We at Benzie County Central Schools would like to celebrate and remember John Nuske.
John WAS in fact Lake Ann, and he also was a proud Benzie Central Husky supporter, and a strong supporter and advocate for our band program. John was a member of our Husky family.
John was a long time member of the Benzie County Central Schools Board of Education. He was the board member who made the official motion to add an auditorium to the bond proposals being crafted in the late 1990's. Thank you, John!
John and his wife Sandy had three children attend Benzie Central Schools, all very active and involved. Mike Eagan, former Benzie Central DIrector (1992-2016) sums it up nicely...."John rarely, if ever, missed any Benzie Central activities, whether they were academic, athletic, or music. After all my concerts and festivals, he would would come up and always have nice words to say."
Benzie Central honors the late John Nuske. Please help us in celebrating him.
Article and photo courtesy of UpNorthLive.

He was the Principal at Betsie Valley Elementary from 2012-2013, as well as the Principal at Platte River Elementary from 2013-2017. Since 2017, Graetz has served Benzie Central Schools at the Middle/High School secondary level, as the Assistant Principal and Athletic Director. Mr. Graetz will continue to provide an enthusiastic and positive demeanor with all students, their families, and our staff. We are pleased to have the leadership of Graetz here at the MS/HS campus to start the 2020/21 school year.
Let’s all welcome Mr. Steve Graetz.

🛑 🐾DISTRICT COMMUNICATION🐾🛑
2020/21.....What does it look like?
Though a winding road, we will continue to navigate.
It has been two weeks since Governor Whitmer released the State’s 63-page plan for re-opening schools in Michigan (June 30, 2020). The recommendations and requirements vary based on the status of the Coronavirus Pandemic (COVID-19), in our geographic area at any given time during the school year. Our Benzie County Central Schools Administration and staff are diligently developing multiple plans; each with different safety protocols, for the various phases.
We fully anticipate starting school on our official first day of school, Tuesday, September 8, 2020 (HALF DAY). We thank our entire school community, especially our current students and families, for their continued support of Benzie County Central Schools. Please stay tuned for more information in the coming days and weeks.
Enjoy the sunshine and all that is good...safely!
GO HUSKIES!

Oral History Project turns focus to present amid pandemic

“BENZIE COUNTY — Four student interns from Benzie Central High School began their school year by interviewing individuals who had played a role in Benzie County's past, but now they are finishing their school year by turning their focus to history in the making.
These interns — Reeve Katt, AuSable Kreiner, Melia Lorenz and Finn McLaren — have spent the past nine months interviewing local individuals of all walks of life, using their training from the University of Michigan School of Information and professional recording equipment purchased through a grant from the Institute of Museum and Library Services.
They had expected to conclude their many interviews with the legacy portion of the internship this spring. This called for them to interview — for 90 minutes each — two individuals who had played key roles in Benzie County's history, however, COVID-19 had other plans.” -Record Patriot

Benzie Central High School - Jasmine Makayla Kenner.
Copemish, Michigan
Jasmine is the daughter of Tony and Diane Kenner.
Jasmine enjoys playing softball, hanging out with friends, going to the beach, and camping.
When asked about her favorite teacher, Jasmine replied, "Mrs. Fagerstrom, my TBA CTC Allied Health teacher. She never once gave up on me, and she made sure that I understood the material. She also was a friend when and if I needed it."
What advice would Jasmine give to those students still in school? "Get involved! Never give up, and push yourself."
Jasmine plans to attend Schoolcraft College in Livonia, to become a medical assistant.
Jasmine would like to leave us all with this, "Be who you are and say what you feel, because those who mind don't matter and those who matter don't mind" - Dr. Seuss
Congratulations, Jasmine. Our Husky hats are off to you. We extend our senior salute.

"Husky Hats Off - Senior Salute"❤️🐾🎓
Benzie Central High School - Jagger Benjamen Richards.
Interlochen, Michigan
Jagger is the son of Jenny King and Stephen King.
Jagger enjoys working on cars and going two tracking.
"My favorite memories while in high school are in class with Mr. Jones. We had great laughs in Welding class when Mr. Jones would tell his stories."
When asked about his favorite teacher, Jagger replied, Mr. Lovendusky. "He could always turn the mood into something good, no matter what."
What advice would Jagger give to those students still in school? "Always try to better yourself. Go the distance for the best in things."
Jagger intends to pursue his career in the military. He is also starting an apprenticeship at TopLine Electric to become an electrician.
Jagger would like to leave us all with this, "We all have big changes in our lives that are more or less a second chance."
-Harrison Ford
Congratulations, Jagger. Our Husky hats are off to you. We extend our senior salute.
#benziecentraldistrictfacebookpage✅

Herrljunga, Sweden | Beulah, Michigan.

Her favorite memory during her year at Benzie Central? "Running Cross Country, and being a part of such a great team."

Lisa intends to finish her education in Sweden, and pursue a career in Architecture or Civil Engineering.
Lisa would like to leave us all with this, "Doubt kills more dreams than failure ever will."
Congratulations, Lisa. Our Husky hats are off to you. We extend our senior salute.

"Husky Hats Off - Senior Salute"❤️🐾🎓
Benzie Central High School - Evan Christopher Milks.
Benzonia, Michigan
Evan is the son of Johnny and Erica Milks.
Evan's interests lie within the construction and mechanic realm. He loved attending the Career Tech. Center for their Construction Trades Program, and he enjoyed working in the shop while at Benzie Central.
Evan's favorite memory was riding the TBA bus with both A.J., and Tobyn.
When asked about his favorite teacher, Evan replied, Mr. Jones. "Mr. Jones taught me a lot about mechanics and welding. He pushes me to keep learning more."
Advice that Evan would want to give to those students still in school? "Listen to what your teachers want you to do. You will pass if you pay attention."
After high school, Evan wants to immediately get to work in the construction field. Within a few years, he would like to earn his building license, so that he can open his own business and work for himself.
Congratulations, Evan. Our Husky hats are off to you. We extend our senior salute.
#benziecentraldistrictfacebookpage✅

“The group Alabama has a song “Angels among us”. During this crisis we all know they exist. Health Care, 1st Responders, truckers. The list can go on and on. This morning I worked with some of these angels.
My home school district Benzie Cental Schools are delivering meals twice a week. I helped load and road along. 6600 meals today...lasting through the weekend. 16 buses and dozens of mainly school employees with some volunteers. Making sure these kids are fed...and even more so letting them know that their school family cares.
When I saw those buses lining up and the workers moving with precision. Superintendent Matt Olson directing the efforts. I got emotional. The site of it all...to make sure children are cared for.
I know many other districts are doing similar things. But this morning I was very proud to be among them!”
-State Representative, Jack O’Malley
#benziecentraldistrictfacebookpage✅

When I saw those buses lining up and the workers moving with precision. Superintendent Matt Olson directing the efforts. I got emotional. The site of it all...to make sure children are cared for.
I know many other districts are doing similar things. But this morning I was very proud to be among them!

"The problem is is that ground creates a barrier for a lot of our families," Olson said.

Olson says parts of the district are rural, low-income and far from big grocery stores. The school district has held food drives before but many families didn’t have the time or resources to make it in person.
